title: Before 1 July 2018, will Waymo launch a driverless transportation service open to the public?
preds: Revising because I didn't read the question properly.
http://fortune.com/2018/03/13/waymo-driverless-minivans-phoenix/ No driver. Resolves as "yes" Early Rider Program without driver "yes".

Nobody in the drivers seat resolves as "yes". "In the video, the passengers giggle nervously at the sight of an empty driver’s seat, wondering aloud whether passersby are also slightly freaked out, and making casual references to “the future.” Then, very quickly, as is common among most ride-hailing passengers, they start to zone out. They look at their phones, they yawn, and one even falls asleep. When they reach their destination, they thank not the driver but the car." https://youtu.be/QqRMTWqhwzM https://www.theverge.com/platform/amp/2018/3/13/17114194/waymo-driverless-minivan-arizona-early-rider-video
edit.  guessing that article is referring to the early rider program
Too many hurdles, to short a time frame

I continue the to believe the pilot in Chandler satisfies this question. Wait is also posting more jobs for Chandler via linked in (ex dispatcher). I realize 3.5 months isn’t long to completely set up (let call what they have a geo-fenced proof of concept; they will move to a pilot).
Looks like at lot of obstacles still exist before they go live, and time is running out.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-selfdriving-waymo/waymo-seeks-to-reassure-potential-riders-with-new-self-driving-video-idUSKCN1GC0VO
Alas, "in coming months" is not helpful in this context--an effectively infinite number of months are coming.   Inching up, just in case.  I suppose I'll have to start paying attention to this again.
No date mentioned but it’s looking more and more likely in AZ. https://arstechnica.com/cars/2018/02/robotaxi-permit-gets-arizonas-ok-waymo-will-start-service-in-2018/
based on current website - it appears they are already doing this.

https://www.engadget.com/2018/02/24/fully-driverless-car-tests-california-april/ Automakers testing their self-driving cars on California roads might be able to go fully autonomous as soon as April, . . .  the companies will be required to link their cars to remote operators. Those remote drivers' job is to keep an eye on multiple cars and to take over their controls if and when needed. The automakers are allowed to hire third-party companies to handle remote operation. Some of them, though, including Waymo and Nissan, have already developed their own remote-driving technologies . . . .
. . . 
The DMV believes California's legal compliance agency will approve the new regulations by February 26th. It will welcome comments from the public starting March 1st and could start handing out permits by April 2nd. According to the DMV's website, a total of 50 companies have permission to test their cars in California, so at least few dozen giant corporations and startups are probably already preparing to secure permits under the new regulations.

We are beginning to see back-up drivers move into the backseat. Also, enrollment into Early Riders is being solicited. Attitudes change in favor of AVs, as per AAA. The overall prospect is good enough for a high prob estimate.
The technology will not be ready by Jul 2018
Alphabet will need the marketing buzz generated by launching even within a small limited market.
To keep up with Uber and Lyft
Waymo is leading other companies in the development of self driving cars. The legal permissions have been obtained and the tests show good progress.
They settled lawsuit with Uber and have received permit.
Increasing due to permit grant. Already contrarian high given Chandler testing which actually could resolve this question as a “yes”.
Waymo consistently gets ahead of itself with its stated calendar of deliverables.

They seem to be on track to do this in 2018.  https://arstechnica.com/cars/2018/02/robotaxi-permit-gets-arizonas-ok-waymo-will-start-service-in-2018/ I remain optimistic here.  Their experience so far has been good.
Not enough R and D invested in this
Permitting is the most signficant roadblock. Other risks can be managed by limiting the service parameters. They just got their permit.

Waymo is believed to be testing in 25 US cities, winter testing to see if the system will work in  snowy and icy conditions that might obscure traffic signs and road markings. At present, only seven US states allow driverless cars to be used on public roads. Delivery of the vehicles will begin late in 2018 and will require extensive conversion work before they are ready to operate. A full service launch is expected in 2019. “With the world’s first fleet of fully self-driving vehicles on the road, we’ve moved from research and development to operations and deployment,” said Waymo CEO John Krafcik. 
http://www.prodrivermags.com/news/785-waymo-gears-up-for-us-autonomous-ride-share-service-launch-in-2019

I remain unconvinced that the decision tree dilemma faced by driverless vehicle algorithms will be solved by Waymo sufficiently to allow DPTS within the forecasting period. I would suggest it as more likely that a period of at least 18 months from the closing date will elapse before this is even fit to present to DOT in the USA. I would however anticipate that Chinese based outfits will achieve this objective within 12 months, primarily because the safety standards are at least a magnitude lower which allows for more critical pathway progress, the key element.
Cars not developed enough, no safety trials reported in media (in Phoenix testing area)

https://www.fool.com/investing/2018/02/13/google-just-made-an-announcement-that-should-terri.aspx
"later this year" - not sure if that before or after July
Though I think the scope will be limited, all players in the recent court case and disputes over driverless tech seem highly motivated to deliver something to market quickly.

For more testing and infrastructure improvements will be necessary before an autonomous car service will be feasible even for testing. The exception would be if this were only in a very tightly controlled area like within a particular neighborhood or subdivision.

This is where technology is headed and to be the 1st to have the new technology is going to be the site of the manufactures I just think  We have our head in the sand if we think it's not going to happen quickly!
Waymo will take advantage of the opportunity to be privy of some Uber activities
Recent COURT case settlement with UBER
Uber and Waymo reached a settlement and that was part of my original forecast
As widespread autonomous vehicle use has not become reality, it is unlikely that a fully automated service will be allowed at this time.
Continue to believe Chandler satisfied (vague) question. Taking down given the question is looking for something other than a geofenced 100 square mile test.

They started with an easy city with good weather that needs self-driving cars because of gambling and free booze while gambling, and  Phoenix gave them permits to shoot video for advertising, but not for actually hauling people around driverless. So? What happens when they get to a tough city to navigate with bad weather and high pedestrian fatalities like Seattle? Four months is a very slim chance. I think they would have had better odds if the riders were blind people over gamblers and tourists.
No. They still need to perform a lot of testing for liability.

This is an interesting one. On one hand, the media reports "later" in 2018.  Conversely, they've just announced a large order of Pacifica's for a fleet rollout. https://techcrunch.com/2018/01/29/waymo-orders-thousands-of-pacificas-for-2018-self-driving-fleet-rollout/ Waymo's Early Rider program is still accepting applications. It doesn't give a time frame. https://waymo.com/apply/
Insurance companies will not have caught up with this tech.  Therefore litigations will be massive if all is not in place.
No. Technology is not so far developed. They may will show a "driverless car" but there will be still a driver (as in emergency operator) in the car.
Despite gaining regulatory approval, technical issues and negative public support will keep a self driving car service from launching in 2018.
I don't see how any company can get through the liability question for an 'open to the public' distribution system within the next 18-24 months.
Waymo indicates they will launch in the "later" part of 2018.

No change in forecast but article references Phoenix service (“this year”). They are already using 600 minivans to test software with “thousands” more on the way. Atlanta Georgia up next. https://www.wired.com/story/waymo-launches-self-driving-minivans-fiat-chrysler/
Their testing has proved the vehicle can operate as intended

Waymo plans to launch a driverless commercial service (meaning no human test drivers) this year.
http://fortune.com/2018/01/22/google-waymo-self-driving-minivans-atlanta/ this year but will be by 1 July? There is no set date, which makes me nervous.

I continue to believe this question has already been satisfied at Level 4 autonomy. If they’re looking for L5, not happening this year. I realize some caveats (geofences and limited speed) but no one behind wheel.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanohnsman/2017/11/07/our-driverless-future-begins-waymo-transitions-to-robot-chauffeurs/

They are already testing autonomous cars without safety driver. They must've decided that based on the intervention rate which must have reached an acceptable level. Then testing without a safety driver is probably simply a test against the passengers' psychological impact, which should take too long.

Not sure what the big deal is.  The New York State Thruway has been, to all appearances, largely driverless for many decades.  Smartphones have made it worse, of course, but pretty much every day one sees automobiles in which the left front seat is occupied by someone who is reading or writing or apparently napping.

The technology is not ready yet. Dateline 12-20-2017 The technology just hasn’t been proved safe, either to the satisfaction of road-safety regulators or even to that of the car makers themselves. Case in point: Volvo, the car company whose middle name is safety, has just deferred a driverless pilot program that had been scheduled for next year in Gothenburg; the program is now on for 2021.  Why all the backing and filling? Quite probably the more ambitious claims were made by suits in the C suite and then walked back by engineers in the lab. The original big, fat promise, by Brin [Waymo's CEO], was certainly in line with Silicon Valley business culture, which is to talk big and apologize later, if at all. https://spectrum.ieee.org/cars-that-think/transportation/self-driving/the-year-in-robocars Dateline 1-4-2018  Actual self-driving cars—with no one behind the wheel—will enter commercial service in 2018. You may now exhale. Yes, it’s true, but here’s the caveat: The service will be severely circumscribed. At most, we’ll see robocars serving as taxis in certain well-mapped suburbs. At least, we’ll see passenger-free robocars that reposition themselves by night so that commuters can have access to them come morning. But that’s still what experts call Level 4 autonomy. Here’s the hierarchy: At Level 5, a car can do it all. At Level 4, the car does it all only in certain areas, under certain conditions. At Level 3, drivers must be prepared to take control after a 10-second warning. At Level 2, they must pay attention all the time. Level 1 helps with the braking. Level 0 has power windows. Level 2 is available now from GM. Level 3 is supposedly possible for Audi’s newly unveiled A8, at least when the safety regulators in your city say so. And Level 4 is just about every car company’s goal—for 2021. True, in early November Waymo took the big step of removing the safety driver from behind the wheel of its ride-hailing robocar service near Phoenix, Ariz.—only to plonk that driver down in the back seat, just in case. And even that program is still free of charge to only a select group of subscribing riders and therefore more of a demo than a real business proposition. -- https://spectrum.ieee.org/transportation/self-driving/the-first-fully-commercial-robocar-will-be-in-holland
Too many accidents thanks to defective autopilot, self driving vehicles. Thanks @dsarin f0r reporting some of these http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/678934

Tesla ‘on Autopilot’ slams into parked fire truck on California freeway
https://www.mercurynews.com/2018/01/22/tesla-on-autopilot-slams-into-parked-fire-truck-on-freeway/
the number of news items on driverless cars are increasing and the public is ready to see it in action after all the talking
There are so many levels of regulation they will need to go through to make this service open to the public.

I feel the initiative in Chandler (Phoenix) with 100 minivans in use by early rider program satisfies criteria. No google employee or operator behind wheel - completely autonomous. The area is geo-fenced (geographically limited) but I don’t see that as part of criteria.

Oh, golly!  I thought I had adjusted this a long, long time ago!

We are not ready for the technology yet !

Regulatory requirements will be hard to meet although there is a substantial market currently for this type service. The service is likely to be offered first in Silicon Valley and then other California cities before moving up the coast to Washington then Oregon then Colorado. Once there is a demonstrated safe experience with the service, a significant number of states will join the movement but Red states will be the last to pass regulatory permissions.
Google have been working on self driving cars since 2009, the announcement was made on November 2017
It will probably be limited to certain areas first so that it can be tested as to how accurate they will be
I would expect regulations to dictate that a safety operator be in the drivers seat.

Waymo early rider program has already began in phoenix and as the question states this is counted in the prediction.  it will probably take until 2019 for the program to role out in a large extent but it is a great first step.
The more I'm reading, the more I am thinking that the deadline is a little too soon.
This appears to be already happening on the Early Rider Programme in Phoenix.

To launch a product before 1 July 2018, it means, the product is set, all engineering kinks removed, all manufacting issues cleaned, software is actively responding and supply chain is set, but I don't think that's the case in this instance. Less then 5 pct chance, they will be ready before 1 July 2018. Manufacturing and software setbacks, look to 2019 for a launch date.

Problems relating to safely operating an driverless vehicle will prove more difficult to identify and resolve than anticipated. As a result, insurance companies will be unwilling to provide liability insurance to Waymo
To early for them, need more time

A few technical difficulties, also there will be push back from the city counsel on the idea because of the financial and tax end of the project. There will also be push back from taxi drivers and companies who will push to delay the release. Ultimately there will be a release but probably 2019

It's hard to parse out how much impact Waymo/google has on California road regulations for the roadway access that comprises the Waymo project. They might have a lot of influence over being able to offer a driverless passenger service in and around Google town. Otherwise: chances are slim
- timeframe seems to be between 3 years and as much as 10, with expectations for a noticeable reduction in driven-vehicles by 2030
Obstacles include:
-Business -- Delivery and transport companies -- heavily invested in current hardware
- driverless might mean a reduction in accidents (or not as in Pacifica and Tesla 'white' van test) but it doesn't mean zero deaths so - liability, 
regulations, 
perceptions about reliability and safety still remain
Testing is one thing, launching a driverless transportation service is another.  Lots of probable challenges to overcome in a short period of time.

The first company will dominate the market in this field that manages this challenge good enough. The main capabilities in this field Google have, managing IT challenges on large scale. Google has Big Computer Resources, with GoogleMind world class experts in Machine Learning, with Google Map exact Road Information, with Android the leading Operating System for mobiles. Google is world class in processing Viewing, Imaging, Video. Google practices successfully different stages of autonomy with this type of mechanical device including before mentioned IT capabilities. I believe Google is ready for going public with good enough service by mid 2018 and will do it.

Safety, technology and testing and domain questions were pretty much answered to my satisfaction in the first three articles that were linked. A Ford spokesman had an interesting caveat but it was minor and I discounted it because The Chrysler Pacifica and its 84 mpg got Waymo's business.  Ford also didn't mention Waymos partnership for fleet services with AVIS. This brought up the American business cycle which shows no signs of collapse in the next couple quarters. Chrysler's Pacifica has anomalous sales figures for November and December, Avis report to Barclays Bank revealed beautiful synergies for the immediate and long term potentials. Can you imagine WAYMO shuttles at AVIS airport rentals to smooth out rental peaks? Avis is already working with AMAZON ALEXA, ALexa and Google HOME, are selling well, Google a device per second since October. Of course we have phones too. Everything seems to be moving lockstep.  Waymo seems to be moving in 6 month increments, I'd guess MAY 1st. There are no legislative barriers to impede this date in Arizona but there is  A trial WAYMO vs UBER: https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/4609586/waymo-llc-v-uber-technologies-inc/?filed_after=&filed_before=&entry_gte=&entry_lte=&order_by=desc  This indicates a February Jury trial standing between now and July. Allegedly UBER stole trade secrets and I can imagine reverse liability if WAYMO went to market with this loose string left untied.  I think Google has a great chance to win. APPLE just rewon versus Samsung in November and WAYMO's parent company has the money to sustain appeals which should push the trial in WAYMOS direction  so I think there are huge amounts of tech, economic, demand and courts momenta to push this through by July.

The regulatory climate is welcoming.  The technology appears to be there.  Alphabet/Waymo is motivated to convince the public that self-driving cars can be a reality.  Arizone presents very few weather-related problems.  (I'm assuming this would take place in Arizona, but the possibility that it would be elsewhere only drives the probability up.)   One hitch I have with the question is exactly what a "driverless transportation service" is -- Waymo is already offering rides for free in Chandler, just outside of (or part of?) Phoenix, according to its Medium page and Ars Technica.  I'm assuming that the question means a pay-for-service arrangement.  That is, will Waymo offer to the public a service whereby riders pay to be taken from one place to another by a driverless car?  I look at 1 July 2018 as promising.  However, my answer would be much higher, probably close to 80%, if the question were regarding all of 2018 - that is, until 1 January 2019.

https://www.theverge.com/2017/11/8/16626224/las-vegas-self-driving-shuttle-crash-accident-first-day http://www.businessinsider.com/waymo-ends-publishing-self-driving-car-accident-reports-website-2017-1 http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Waymo-self-driving-minivan-has-different-type-of-12188714.php Too many questions left to answer related to safety.   https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/auto

Waymo is already offering the participants in the early rider program the ability to test their vehicles as much as possible. If a service offered to Waymo’s early rider participants counts, as the question says, then it’s already happening.

The technology may be ready, as may the consumers, but on issues like this the cognizant regulatory agencies can usually be outrun by a reasonably brisk glacier.  Even with permissive statutes in place, substantial hemming and hawing opportunities are available.  Stay tuned. (You remember glaciers, right?  Good.  Take photos for your grandchildren, who mightn't have any experience of them.)

Yeah I think this will be launched, and then I think we will find out the technology was rushed. I don't think that for any particular reason, and I do think autonomous vehicles are the future, but in my experience the first time anything is done there are unexpected bugs.

Phoenix, AZ will be most likely location where Waymo will be allowed to provide driverless car service based on the combination of low regulation, relatively low traffic density, and good driving weather. Waymo has already been providing limited rides to the public since August during its initial beta test. There will likely be limits to the service offered; geolocation fencing and weather restrictions being some examples. I believe that permission will be granted sometime next Spring. Waymo has already signed agreements with Carmax and Avis as maintenance and automobile providers. Potential barriers to full approval include (1) unanticipated accidents/malfunctions involving the AI or sensors or (2) unanticipated issues with the cars. Indeed, the Chrysler Pacific minivan (which Waymo is currently using) has had several reports of sudden engine shut off. If this problem is not resolved quickly, Waymo may be forced to redesign their fleet using another car, which may require AI reprogramming, potentially delaying the public launch. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/20/business/chrysler-pacifica.html?hpw&rref=automobiles&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=well-region&region=bottom-well&WT.nav=bottom-well

Waymo CEO John Krafick shared the company’s milestone during a speech Tuesday at the Lisbon Web Summit. For now, these fully self-driving minivans—sans human test driver—are limited to a defined “geo-fenced” area. This means the vehicles can only drive in a specific geographic area. The self-driving cars are completing all aspects of driving however, such as the more complicated left-hand turns. The area will expand and eventually cover a large portion of the sprawling metropolis of Phoenix, about 600 square miles. Waymo is going to let people, not just Google employees, ride in these self-driving minivans, Krafcik said, adding that the company is also going to launch a driverless ride-hailing service.

They are so close already.  Arizona is a great place.  The weather is inviting.  Roads are clean and well signed.  They are already removing shadow drivers from some vehicles. At first I was trying to break the question in pieces asking new questions. Is there legislation prohibiting the driverless transportation? I found out that in 2017 33 states have introduced legislation. Last year, 20 states introduced legislation. (ncsl.org) National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has a vision 2.0 for automated safety tech. In The next years there should be partially automated safety features. In 2025+ there would be fully automatized such as highway pilot. But this discusses only about safety feature. But so far whenever reading about this topic it is "safety first" perspective in all of these articles. Few weeks ago I joined for travel safety webinar and there was a discussion about self-driving cars. The expert told that the technology is doing well, but there's a problem putting those automated cars in the streets with cars with drivers. So it would require a huge turn-up in regulations to diminish the regular cars. I believe that the near future is about driver assistant auto-piloting, but the totally driverless cars won't happen in terms of regulation. At least not in wide scope. BUT I think there is still chance for trials! In Finland we have had driverless transportation in trade show areas past years. It was also mentioned in the introduction that there has already been a trial in Arizona. So if Waymo makes it, it will most like be a trial. The open-to-public service will not be a sort of taxi service. Rather a short distance between A to B. Still it would be counted regarding the layout of the question that lies here. So in the end I would give it quite a high percentage of change to occur 75% but still leaving 25% not happening. Hope this helps you fellow forecasters!
The tech side may be ready, but the cognizant regulatory agencies will have to pray over this for a longer time than this Q allows, I suspect.
The technology exists, but I’d expect a lot of red tape, safety concerns, and unionization against it.

It's a very short list but they did a promo video with one of the families that are a part of the Early Rider Program already.  https://medium.com/waymo/apply-to-be-part-of-waymos-early-rider-program-5fd996c7a86f "They’re [the family highlighted] among the very first people in the world to take part in Waymo’s early rider program" The only change since April is that Waymo announced in November that they plan to remove the safety driver entirely for participants.  However, this aspect is not required to satisfy the rule.
